mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reviving the Bones of the Prophets
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Re-Evaluating the Status of the Hebrew Bible Collection of Smaller Prophetic Writings in the Dead Sea Scrolls and the Late Second Temple Period

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Recent scholarship on the Hebrew Bible's collection of shorter prophetic writings (often referred to as the "Minor Prophets," "The Twelve," or "The Book of the Twelve") presents conclusions that rely heavily on the redaction of the Masoretic text and is quick to point to three primary ancient sources as evidence that these writings reached final formation of a single, homogeneous "Book of the Twelve" prior to the beginning of the second century BCE: 1) antique sources that purportedly record lists of authoritative texts in ancient Judaism, 2) manuscript evidence found among the Dead Sea Scrolls, and 3) quotations and allusions to the shorter prophetic writings in literature of the late Second Temple period.. These primary sources are: 1) Jewish Writings from the late Second Temple period (namely Sirach 49:10, Josephus' Contra Apionem 37–42, and 4 Ezra 14:44–48), as well as Rabbinic (Baba Bathra 14b) and early Christian literature produced after-the Second Temple period that appear to describe a "canon" of the Hebrew Bible; 2) Fragmentary manuscripts from the Dead Sea Scrolls that preserve various books from the shorter prophetic writings; and 3) Quotations and allusions to the shorter prophetic writings in late Second Temple Jewish literature. However, when these sources undergo a rigorous study, it is evident that the current scholarly consensus is steeped in anachronistic categories that privilege interpretations of the material that limit presume the ancient organization of the shorter prophetic writings of the Hebrew Bible adhered to a form that is nearly analogous to the Masoretic tradition. As will be shown, such conclusions would have been foreign to Jewish communities in the late Second Temple period and do not adequately reflect the pluriform state of these prophetic texts prior to 100 CE. This study aims to re-evaluate the status of the Hebrew Bible shorter prophetic writings in the late Second Temple period (250 BCE – 100 CE) by examining the primary source materials in their historical, linguistic, and cultural context. Viewing these sources in their antique ancient setting shows that this prophetic literature was not viewed exclusively as a single fixed collection in the late Second Temple period analogous to the Masoretic text, but instead circulated in disparate collections, ranging from a single prophetic book to multiple books in varying arrangements, that differed based on the preferences of the community preserving the texts. This study also provides an example of how to apply these conclusions to reconstructing fragmentary manuscripts of the shorter prophetic writings. Coupling the conclusions of this study with pioneering methods to digitally reconstruct 4Q77, the material evidence suggests that this manuscript, like others from the Dead Sea Scrolls, provides inconclusive evidence that all twelve of the shorter prophetic books appeared predictably on scrolls in antiquity. Instead the material and literary evidence suggests that there were disparate collections of the shorter prophetic writings circulating during the late Second Temple period, a conclusion that is supported by later evidence in Jewish and Christian writings of the early centuries CE. This study will show that while the texts of the shorter prophetic writings were viewed as authoritative by most Jewish communities at this time, each book remained influx and lacked a concrete identity in relation to one another. Taken together, this study concludes that while Jewish communities appear to have viewed the shorter prophetic writings of the Hebrew Bible as among the authoritative prophetic literature of ancient Judaism, their organization was still fluid in structure and arrangement well into the second century CE.
